content.description: <math alttext="Reaction 1: N H 3, aqueous, plus H with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, react to produce N H 4 with a positive 1 charge ,aqueous" overflow="scroll"> <mtable columnalign="center left"> <mtr> <mtd> <mi>Reaction</mi> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mn>1</mn> <mo>:</mo> </mtd> <mtd> <msub> <mi>NH</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mpadded> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mpadded> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi> <mo>+</mo> </msup> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </mpadded> <mo>→</mo> <msup> <msub> <mi>NH</mi> <mn>4</mn> </msub> <mo>+</mo> </msup> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </mtd> </mtr> </mtable> </math>
content.question: <math alttext="Reaction 2: 2 H 2 O 2, liquid, reacts to produce 2 H 2 O liquid, plus O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnalign="center left"><mtr><mtd><mi>Reaction</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mo>:</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> Which of the following statements about the reactions represented above is true?

choices.label: Reaction 1 cannot be a redox reaction because total charge is conserved.

Reaction 1 is a redox reaction because the nitrogen atom transfers electrons to the <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> ion.
Reaction 2 cannot be a redox reaction because both the reactant and the products have neutral charge.
Reaction 2 is a redox reaction because there is a transfer of electrons between the oxygen atoms.

content.answer: Reaction 2 is a redox reaction because there is a transfer of electrons between the oxygen atoms.

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
